docs.title: Local Rule: Clean lab
docs.text:
Key rules1

  • LABEL your stuff
  • DO NOT suck any liquid into the pipette itself
  • NEVER pipet from a stock standard solution
  • If you have even the slightest suspicion about having contaminated a standard, REPORT (large quantity) or DUMP (small quantity)

docs.title: General rules
docs.text:
• No unauthorised access to the lab suite. Access to the lab suite is controlled via code access. The responsible PI ensures adequate measures are in place to ensure anyone they grant lab access to will be adequately trained/supervised.
  • No unauthorised working in the labs. Before doing any work in the lab, all lab users must (i) complete the Earth Sciences Safety Induction and Fire Safety Training, (ii) read the Lab Manual, this Local Rules document and all relevant Risk Assessments, and (iii) sign the ‘Induction and Authorisation to work declaration’ to affirm that they have read, understood and agree to abide by the protocols detailed in these documents.
  • Risk assessments2 must be in place for existing procedures (and completed and approved by an appropriate assessor for any new procedure) before work is carried out.
  • Before working independently (i.e., not under direct supervision), the responsible PI must countersign the above Induction declaration to state that the lab user is safe, competent, and adequately trained to work without direct supervision.
  • All users must be trained in HF3 safety protocols, whether they will be using HF or not. HF users must receive additional HF training. The responsible PI must countersign the Induction declaration to state that the user is authorised to use HF.
  • No lone working. A paired worker (“buddy”) system is in operation in laboratories on the 2nd floor. Pairing must be positive, i.e., each person should be concerned about the other’s safety. For work over long periods, regular checking on the other person is essential. HF should only be used in the presence of another lab user.
  • No unauthorised working out of hours. After hours working is permitted on a case-by-case basis and risk assessments must explicitly address out of hours working. Authorisation must be given by the responsible PI (or for student work, the student’s supervisor) on the Induction declaration form to the effect that the lab user is safe and competent to work out of hours.

docs.title: Personal Protective Equipment and Safety
docs.text:
• Outdoor shoes must be taken off in the lobby before the step-over bench, and lab clogs must be worn inside the lab.
  • Lab coats must be worn in the clean lab at all times, and not removed from the lab or lobby (i.e., not used in other labs in the department).
  • When handing acids or acidified samples, safety gloves and safety glasses must be worn.
  • Absolutely no food or drink can be taken into the lobby or laboratory or consumed there.

docs.title: Local Rule: MC-ICP-MS (Nu Plasma 3) lab
docs.text:
Key rules

  • LABEL your belongings
  • Remove your belongings from the MC-ICP-MS lab after completing your measurements, MC-ICP-MS lab is not your storage room!

docs.title: Personal Protective Equipment and Safety
docs.text:
• Outdoor shoes must be taken off in the lobby before the step-over bench, and lab clogs must be worn inside the lab.
  • When handing acids or acidified samples, safety gloves and safety glasses must be worn.
  • When handling components of the mass spectrometer (e.g. cones, lenses, torches, etc.), gloves must be worn.
  • Absolutely no food or drink can be taken into the laboratory or consumed there.

docs.title: Hazards
docs.text:
• Dilute mineral acids (2% HNO3) are used to introduce samples into the mass spectrometer. The relevant RA must be read, and necessary PPE must be used.
  • The mass spectrometer uses high voltages. Hardware restrictions prevent access to high voltage systems while they are operational. Only authorised users (lab managers and technicians) may work on the high voltage systems.
  • Radio Frequency (RF) source power. Hardware restrictions prevent access to RF system while operational. General laboratory users can only access to the RF power switch (ON/OFF). Only authorised users (lab managers and technicians) may work on the RF system.
  • High temperature and UV-emitting plasma is used inside the mass spectrometer. The plasma is contained and the plasma power supply is interlocked and cannot be accessed while operating. The plasma is also shielded to prevent escape of UV radiation.
  • Compressed inert gases1 are used to run the mass spectrometer. This is primarily argon, which is used to feed the plasma. Argon is fed from an external tank. Small amounts of nitrogen are occasionally fed into the introduction system, and compressed air is used to keep some valves open. Inlet gas regulators are checked annually, and the instrument regulators are monitored by instrument software.

docs.title: Version History
docs.text:
• 2023-09-11:
    • Copy from Local Rules for the UCL MC-ICP-MS lab (Version: 2021).
    • Add: Key rules.

  1. The lab air volume of ~110 m3 is, at the time of writing, replaced 28 times per hour, equalling an air volume ~3080 m3 per hour. This means that any catastrophic release of gas would have to be very fast to overcome this system. The gas flows themselves are regulated by software-controlled valves within the mass spectrometer. The valves are kept open by compressed air, so that in the case of a failure, the valves will shut.

    Therefore, even in the highly unlikely double catastrophic failure of the air handling and the gas regulators, and power to the mass spectrometer, the gas valves would still shut.

    The laboratory contains oxygen depletion alarms, monitoring both a low level (in case of Ar release) and high level (in case of N2 release). If oxygen depletion alarms are sounding (alarm at entrance to lab), do not enter, but determine cause of alarm (argon or nitrogen), and contact lab managers. ↩

docs.text:
1. switch on cooling water: 20°C
  2. switch on Ar (2 valves): ~95
  3. extraction on the wall: 16 (now 19?), always on
  4. check waste & rinse tank
    • rinse tank: 2–4% HNO3 1L
    • dump waste
  5. pos1 2%, pos3: 4%, pos80: tune solution
  6. peri-pump tubing, do not wait too long before go to pos3, and then go to tune solution
  7. plasma
    • Plasma–Startup Configuration, cf. xxx.xls file

    • Warm-up: 15 mins, 5 mins is enough, can skip, better not?

docs.title: Shutdown
docs.text:
1. plasma off, until solid orange
  2. Switch off cooling water
  3. Ar gas (switch & valve)
  4. peri-pump tubing
  5. close lids for Pos1, Pos3
  6. vial for tune solution: pour into “used tune”, rinse

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Check
    • Tune on (clockwise) the gas regulators on the wall: Ar = 80–110, N2 = 0–10
    • Chiller: water level
  2. Change or install nebuliser
  3. Check autosampler: horizontal (check by going to Home and then Wash) & vertical position
  4. Aridus
    1. drain Peripump
    2. Go to MQ or 2% HNO3
    3. Power on
    4. AridusLink: Spray Chamber 110°C, Desolvator 140°C. ~30 mins
    5. Purge the system with Ar Sweep Gas 3.0 L/min (N2 addition Gas 10 mL/min) for 5 mins
  5. Change cones
    • sample cone: wet || dry
    • skimmer cone:
      • Mo, Zn, Ni, Ba: HS1-7 Ni 58653
  6. Digital–tab Extras, turn on:
    • Peripump
    • Chiller Switch
      • Check chiller Water Flow in the monitor panel in the bottom-right of the screen: >2 L/min
  7. Ignite the plasma
    1. Aridus Ar = 0.5, N2 = 0
    2. Plasma Control–green button START: right, left. Peltier should be off when using Aridus (“dry”). After ignition:
    3. Check chiller Water Flow: normally >1, at least >0.9
    4. If HV2 error: Protection–ResetTrips
    5. slowly increase Aridus Ar to ~3 L/min (N2 = 0)
  8. Tune
    1. Autosampler Control: go to tune solution
    2. Setup–Tunning–Download–All, load from a .TUN file
    3. Set Magnet
      1. Upper right corner, choose configuration for Collector ID assignment
      2. Monitor chart in monitor panel: double click to choose Collector IDs/Masses
      3. Scan–Magnet Scans, in Magnet Scans:
        1. Set a range around the mass@Ax
        2. Stop
        3. Move dash line to the peak center (drag with right button of the mouse)
        4. Control–Set Magnet
    4. Tune Aridus for high sensitivity
    5. Tune plasma for high sensitivity in Plasma Control
      1. ?? Coolant
      2. Aux
        • dry cone: 1
      3. Neb(Press.)
        • 27 or 31 ??
        • affect stability, better to be tuned like Aridus Ar
      4. up/down
      5. Obs In/Out: <8
      6. Back/Fwd
    6. Deflector–tab Source, tune for high sensitivity (Refer to Setup–Tuning–Edit Autotune Sequences. Saved in C:\Nu Plasma Files\Instrument Settings\Deflect.dat)
      • Fixed: HV1 6000, HV4 1875
      • HV 2,3,5,6
        • HV2 always > 2200
      • Tune Source V1 & V2 together, Tune Source H1 & H2 together
      • Transfer DL
      • Transfer H1
      • Transfer V1, V2
      • HV 2,3
    7. Deflector–tab Quad, tune for peak shape (resolution) and alignment
      • in Magnet Scans:
        • Set a range around the mass@Ax
        • View– Auto-Scale
      • Linked Quads (tune alignment when maintaining shape)
      • Quad 1 peak shape
      • Quad 2 peak alignment
      • Q15 Corr for low mass, Q16 Corr for high mass. Affect both peak shape and alignment
      • ??Lin L/H/Corr
      • ??Cubic
      • Auto
        1. choose 2 cups
        2. Enough range: Start/End Scan
        3. Magnet Scans, Control–Optimize Quad Coincidence
      • Quantification of peak alignment by Monitor–Peak Parallelism, in Peak Parallelism Utility:
        • …??
      • Check resolution for a single ion beam: View–Show peak info
    8. Tune Aridus Ar for optimising stability (may sacrifice sensitivity)
      1. Step increase sweep gas by 0.03
      2. Setup–Preferences–Analysis: tick “User may set analysis mass (eg from mass scan)”
      3. Data Acquisition–Single Run–Isotopic: XxOpt.nrf, 10 runs, peak center for the first run, no peak center after that. After the first run:
        1. Note down Magnet set point: XXX amu in monitor panel, but it is best to confirm the value in a Results file: Axial Masses used: XXX
        2. Scan–Magnet Scans: manually set the magnet at this exact mass position
          • “drag” the cursor using the right mouse button, and Control–Set Magnet
      4. Record in Xx Sweep gas optimisation template.xlsx, and find a plateau
  9. Faraday Noise
    1. close analyser valve, wait for 5 mins
    2. Monitor–Faraday Noise
    3. ?? tick 5 sec integration
    4. SD < 2e-5
  10. Gain
    1. close analyser valve, wait for 5 mins
    2. Calibration–Preamp Gain
      1. Num of cycles: 2, Calibration Volt. (V): 40
      2. Check
        • ?? Gain
        • ?? Error (‰?) should be less than 10
      3. Run & Save Results
  11. Data Acquisition–Batch Run–Setup
    • File–Open, Select Auto Sequence .arf file
    • Options (saved in .Opt file)
      • tab Sequence Settings, test and set Transfer Time (secs)
      • tab Analysis Options
        • untick: Peak Centre during analysis
        • Shut down after run? can be changed during batch run: Set Up–Preferences–Shut down at end of analysis
        • On completion move autosampler to: Wash 1 || a position of Wash/Blank with enough solution left (e.g., with a 50 µl/min nebuliser, 10 ml will drain in 200 mins)
  12. Shutdown
    1. after the sequence is finished, go to MQ or 2% HNO3
    2. Plasma Control–red button STOP. Wait
    3. Digital–tab Extras: Chiller (Peripump is turned off automatically)
    4. Aridus power off (? if Aridus cannot be power off soon, remotely set Aridus: Spray 30°C, Desolvator 80°C)
    5. Tubing: drain for Aridus, …
    6. Change nebuliser?
    7. Autosampler power off
    8. Tune off (anti-clockwise) the gas regulators on the wall (Ar, N2)
    9. Remove your belongings from the MC-ICP-MS lab

docs.text: • 10 mg Sample dissolved in 5ml 4% HNO3, shake in ultrasonic bath, 90 mins, leave it to react overnight, add x ml MQ and/or 2% HNO3 (so that [Ca] < 50 ppm), measure Mg, Ca by ICP-OES for calculating the quantity of “excess Leacher4”

docs.title: Reagents
docs.text:
• Leacher1: 12% NaOCl

    • Recipe: ? grade ?% NaOCl (Fisher Catalog# ?) : MQ = ? : ?
    • Shelf life:

  • Leacher2: 1% H2O2

  • Leacher3: 10% NaCl
  • Leacher4: 6M HCl
  • Precipitant1: 250 g/L (nearly saturated) BaCl2
    • Notes: use Ba(NO3)2 instead? because Cl- (ionic strength) increases the solubility of BaSO4

docs.title: Predefined Processes
docs.text:
• CheckS, either way:
    • centrifuge → Aliquot ? ml → add ? ml Leacher4 & ? ml Precipitant1
    • centrifuge → Aliquot ? ml → measuring S with ICP-OES
  • PrecipitateBaSO4:
    1. heating 85°C, 1h
    2. swirl gently
    3. cooling in fridge, 10 °C, 2h
    4. room T, >=3 days
    5. if there is no precipitate, add 2 mg of isotopic grade S-free quartz powder
    flowchart TD
    %% usually x=5–10, net result: 1–5 mg BaSO4 for "Analyse2"
    Sample(["x g Sample (140–700?? ng CAS)"])

    %% --------------- Leach1
    %% submerge sample powder by Leacher1
    Sample --> Leach1["Step1: 2–4x mL Leacher1, room T, Shake 24h"]:::Leach --> Centrifuge1 --> Result1{Result1}

    %% |"After 3×Leach1"|
    Result1 -->|Leachate1: sulphide/organic matters| CheckS1[[CheckS]]
    %% how to discard??
    CheckS1 -->|Leachate1| Discard1([Discard1])
    CheckS1 --> CheckS1Result{Yes/No}

    Result1 -->|Residual1| Rinse1["Rinse with MQ & Centrifuge"] -->|3| Rinse1 -..-> CheckS1Result

    CheckS1Result -->|"Yes (Residual1, Repeat Leach1 >=3)"| Leach1

    %% --------------- Leach2
    CheckS1Result -->|"No (Residual1)"| Leach2["Step2: 2–4x mL Leacher2, room T, Shake 2–24??h"]:::Leach --> Centrifuge2 --> Result2{Result2}
    Result2 ---|"Leachate2: sulphide/organic matters??"| Discard2([Discard2])
    Result2 -->|Residual2| Rinse2["Rinse with MQ & Centrifuge"] -->|3| Rinse2 --> Dry1["Dry 80°C, ~72?h"]

    %% --------------- Leach3
    %% submerge sample powder by Leacher3
    Dry1 --> Leach3["Step3: 2–4x mL Leacher3, room T, Shake 24h"]:::Leach --> Centrifuge3 --> Result3{Result3}

    Result3 -->|Leachate3: soluble S-bearing constituents| CheckS2[[CheckS]]
    CheckS2 -->|Leachate3| Discard3([Discard3])
    CheckS2 --> CheckS2Result{Yes/No}

    Result3 -->|Residual3| Rinse3["Rinse with MQ & Centrifuge"] -->|3| Rinse3 -..-> CheckS2Result

    CheckS2Result -->|"Yes (Residual3)"| Leach3

    %% --------------- Leach4
    %% <30 mins to prevent oxidation of sulphides
    CheckS2Result -->|"No (Residual3)"| Leach4["Step4: excess Leacher4, room T, <30 mins"]:::Leach --> Filter["Centrifuge & Filter, 0.2 µm PP membrane syringe filter"] --> Result4{Result4}
    Result4 -->|Residual4| Discard4([Discard4])
    Result4 --> Leachate4[/Leachate4/]
    Leachate4 --> Aliquot1["Aliquot1 1 ml, add 4 ml 2% HNO3"] --> Analyse1[["Analyse1 S @ICP-OES"]]:::Analyse

    %% --------------- Precipitate1
    Leachate4 --> Precipitate1["Step5: x/5 ml Precipitant1"]:::Precipitate --> PrecipitateBaSO4[[PrecipitateBaSO4]] --> Centrifuge4 --> Result5{Result5}
    Result5 ---|Supernatant1| Discard5([Discard5])
    Result5 --> Precipitates1[/Precipitates1/]
    Precipitates1 --> Leach5["~5?? ml Leacher4"] --> |Leachate5: BaCO3| Discard6([Discard6])
    Leach5 -->|Residual5| Rinse4["Rinse with MQ & Centrifuge"] -->|3| Rinse4 --> |Supernatant2: salts, including BaCl2| Discard7([Discard7])
    Rinse4 -->|Residual6: CAS in BaSO4| Dry2["Dry 60°C, ~48h"] --> Weigh1 --> Analyse2[["Analyse2 δ34S @EA-IRMS"]]:::Analyse
